awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Fire Influences on Forest Recovery and Associated Ecosystem Feedbacks in Arctic Larch Forests.

por.por_cntn:
Larix cajanderi forests, which occupy vast regions of Siberia, are located on extremely carbon rich permafrost. Regeneration of these forests has important implications for long-term feedbacks into the climate system and their regeneration is strongest following stand-replacing fires. The goal of this project was to assess sources of regeneration limitation in L. cajanderi forests in northeastern Siberia. As part of a large collaborative project, our research focused on (a) regeneration potential of stands varying in density and (b) analyzing seedling establishment patterns in relationship to microsite conditions (“safe sites”) in the landscape, (c) relationships between seedling establishment and mycorrhizal colonization, and (d) tree-ring analysis of stand dynamics. We discovered that the density of trees in a stand was negatively related to the number of cones that the average tree produced, and stands of moderate density produced more cones per area than either high- or low-density forests. Larix cajanderi seedling establishment was facilitated by safe sites in the landscape. We discovered strong evidence that safe sites are considerably more important for seedling establishment in lowland sites than upland areas. The biological explanation for this pattern is presently unknown; however, we hypothesize this pattern is driven by persistently wet (marshy) soils in some lowland sites as a limiter of seedling establishment. We discovered patterns of mycorrhizal fungal colonization were related to seedling success, and that landscape features predicted colonization of seedlings. Tree-ring analysis revealed complex patterns of stand dynamics indicating pulses of regeneration and rapid growth consistent with stand-replacing disturbance as the prevailing disturbance regime. This project resulted in dynamic training opportunities for multiple students. Two student completed MS Degrees in the McEwan Lab at the University of Dayton based on this project, with each student traveling to Siberia and, beyond executing their specific research projects, also contributed to the overall success of the larger collaboration. These students have subsequently graduated and gone on to professional success.  The project also provided the opportunity for an undergraduate researcher (working on the tree-ring project) to achieve research success and professional development as she presented her work at multiple conferences. Data collected by students funded through this project resulted in multiple peer-reviewed journal article and have been archived in the Arctic Data Center, a permanent and publicly accessible archive.
